title: Ilya Sutskever
content:
{{Short description|Computer scientist (born 1985/86)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2023}} {{Use Canadian English|date=February 2023}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Ilya Sutskever | native_name = Илья Суцкевер | birth_name = Илья Суцкевер | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=CAN|FRS|size=100%}} | image = Ilya_Sutskever_and_Sam_Altman_in_TAU.jpg | image_size = | caption = Ilya Sutskever (right) with [[Sam Altman]] at [[Tel Aviv University]] in 2023 | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |29|2015}}{{cite web |last1=Simonite |first1=Tom |title=Ilya Sutskever |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/innovator/ilya-sutskever/ |website=technologyreview.com |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=18 August 2015 |archive-date=15 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230515110629/https://www.technologyreview.com/innovator/ilya-sutskever/ |url-status=live }} | birth_place = [[Nizhny Novgorod|Gorky]], Russian SFSR, Soviet Union{{Cite web |title=Heard It Through the AI {{!}} University of Toronto Magazine |url=https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/alumni-donors/heard-it-through-the-ai-openai-ilya-sutskever/ |access-date=9 October 2022 |website=University of Toronto Magazine |date=28 September 2022 |language=en-US |archive-date=29 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230529042940/https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/alumni-donors/heard-it-through-the-ai-openai-ilya-sutskever/ |url-status=live }}{{cite web |title=Season 1 Ep. 22 Ilya Sutskever |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fCoavgGZ64Y |via=YouTube |publisher=The Robot Brains Podcast |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=21 September 2021 |archive-date=1 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230501143736/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fCoavgGZ64Y |url-status=live }} | death_date = | death_place = | citizenship = Canadian, Israeli | fields = [[Machine learning]]
[[Artificial neural network|Neural networks]]
[[Artificial intelligence]]
[[Deep learning]]{{Google scholar id}} | workplaces = [[University of Toronto]]
[[Stanford University]]
[[Google Brain]]
[[OpenAI]] | alma_mater = {{indented plainlist| * [[Open University of Israel]] * [[University of Toronto]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]], [[Master of Science|MS]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) }} | doctoral_advisor = [[Geoffrey Hinton]]{{MathGenealogy}} | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[AlexNet]]
Co-founding [[OpenAI]] | thesis_title = Training Recurrent Neural Networks | thesis_url = https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/bitstream/1807/36012/6/Ilya_Sutskever_201306_PhD_thesis.pdf | thesis_year = 2013 | influences = | influenced = | awards = | religion = | signature = | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''Ilya Sutskever''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|FRS}} ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɪ|l|j|ə|_|ˈ|s|uː|t|s|k|ɪ|v|ər}}; {{lang-he|איליה סוצקבר}}; {{lang-ru|Илья́ Суцке́вер}} {{IPA|ru|ɪˈlʲja sʊtsˈkʲevʲɪr|}} born 1985/86) is a [[computer scientist]] working in [[machine learning]]. He is a co-founder and Chief Scientist at [[OpenAI]].{{cite news |last1=Metz |first1=Cade |title=A.I. Researchers Are Making More Than $1 Million, Even at a Nonprofit |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/technology/artificial-intelligence-salaries-openai.html?action=click&module=RelatedCoverage&pgtype=Article®ion=Footer |access-date=22 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=19 April 2018 |language=en |archive-date=1 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230301021221/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/technology/artificial-intelligence-salaries-openai.html?action=click&module=RelatedCoverage&pgtype=Article®ion=Footer |url-status=live }} He has made several major contributions to the field of [[deep learning]].{{Cite journal |last1=Krizhevsky |first1=Alex |last2=Sutskever |first2=Ilya |last3=Hinton |first3=Geoffrey E |date=2012 |title=ImageNet Classification with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks |url=https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper/2012/hash/c399862d3b9d6b76c8436e924a68c45b-Abstract.html |journal=Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems |publisher=Curran Associates, Inc. |volume=25}}{{Cite journal |last1=Srivastava |first1=Nitish |last2=Hinton |first2=Geoffrey |last3=Krizhevsky |first3=Alex |last4=Sutskever |first4=Ilya |last5=Salakhutdinov |first5=Ruslan |date=2014 |title=Dropout: A Simple Way to Prevent Neural Networks from Overfitting |url=http://jmlr.org/papers/v15/srivastava14a.html |journal=Journal of Machine Learning Research |volume=15 |issue=56 |pages=1929–1958 |issn=1533-7928}}{{Cite journal |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |last2=Vinyals |first2=Oriol |last3=Le |first3=Quoc V. |date=2014-12-08 |title=Sequence to sequence learning with neural networks |url=https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.5555/2969033.2969173 |journal=Proceedings of the 27th International Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems - Volume 2 |series=NIPS'14 |location=Cambridge, MA, USA |publisher=MIT Press |pages=3104–3112}} In 2023, Sutskever and the OpenAI board fired CEO [[Sam Altman]], who returned a week later. He is the co-inventor, with [[Alex Krizhevsky]] and [[Geoffrey Hinton]], of [[AlexNet]], a [[convolutional neural network]].{{cite q|Q59445836}} Sutskever is also one of the many co-authors of the [[AlphaGo]] paper.{{cite q|Q28005460}} ==Early life and education== Sutskever was born in [[Nizhny Novgorod]], [[Russia]], then called Gorky, at the time part of the [[Soviet Union]], and at age 5 immigrated with his family to [[Israel]].{{Cite news |last=מן |first=יובל |date=2022-11-18 |title="הבינה המלאכותית מהמדע הבדיוני תהפוך למציאות" |language=he |work=Ynet |url=https://www.ynet.co.il/digital/technology/article/h1ebvhxuj |access-date=2023-04-18 |archive-date=18 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230418113604/https://www.ynet.co.il/digital/technology/article/h1ebvhxuj |url-status=live }} He spent his formative years in [[Jerusalem]].{{Cite web |last=Ansari |first=Tasmia |date=2023-03-07 |title=The Brain That Supercharged ChatGPT, ImageNet and TF |url=https://analyticsindiamag.com/the-brain-that-supercharged-chatgpt-imagenet-tensorflow/ |access-date=2023-03-14 |website=Analytics India Magazine |language=en-US |archive-date=14 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230314232358/https://analyticsindiamag.com/the-brain-that-supercharged-chatgpt-imagenet-tensorflow/ |url-status=live }} Sutskever attended the [[Open University of Israel]] between 2000 and 2002.{{cite web |title=Neural networking |url=https://thevarsity.ca/2010/10/25/neural-networking/ |website=The Varsity |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=25 October 2010 |archive-date=8 June 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200608205112/https://thevarsity.ca/2010/10/25/neural-networking/ |url-status=live }} After that, he moved to Canada with his family and attended to the [[University of Toronto]] in [[Ontario]]. From the University of Toronto, Sutskever received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[mathematics]] in 2005,{{cite web |last1=Johnston |first1=Jessica Leigh |date=8 December 2010 |title=A Neural Network for a New Millennium |url=https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/students/ilya-sutskever-google-phd-fellowship/ |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=University of Toronto Magazine |archive-date=14 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230414064407/https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/students/ilya-sutskever-google-phd-fellowship/ |url-status=live }}{{Linkedin}} a [[Master of Science]] in [[computer science]] in 2007,{{cite thesis |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |title=Nonlinear multilayered sequence models |year=2007 |hdl=1807/119676 |url=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/119676 |website=utoronto.ca |publisher=University of Toronto |oclc=234120052 |degree=MSc |language=en |access-date=24 March 2023 |archive-date=24 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230324150814/https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/119676 |url-status=live }} and a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in computer science in 2013.{{cite thesis |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |title=Training Recurrent Neural Networks |year=2013 |hdl=1807/36012 |url=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/36012 |website=utoronto.ca |publisher=University of Toronto |id={{ProQuest|1501655550}} |oclc=889910425 |degree=PhD |language=en |access-date=24 March 2023 |archive-date=26 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230326022642/https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/36012 |url-status=live }}{{cite web |title=RAM Workshop |url=http://www.thespermwhale.com/jaseweston/ram/ |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=thespermwhale.com |archive-date=5 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221205110829/http://www.thespermwhale.com/jaseweston/ram/ |url-status=dead }}{{cite web |title=Episode 85: A Conversation with Ilya Sutskever |url=https://voicesinai.com/episode/episode-85-a-conversation-with-ilya-sutskever/ |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=Voices in AI |publisher=Gigaom |archive-date=22 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230322223929/https://voicesinai.com/episode/episode-85-a-conversation-with-ilya-sutskever/ |url-status=live }} His doctoral supervisor was [[Geoffrey Hinton]]. In 2012, Sutskever built [[AlexNet]] in collaboration with Hinton and [[Alex Krizhevsky]]. To support the computing demands of AlexNet, Sutskever bought many [[GTX 580]] GPUs online.{{Cite web |title=Exclusive: Ilya Sutskever, OpenAI's chief scientist, on his hopes and fears for the future of AI |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/10/26/1082398/exclusive-ilya-sutskever-openais-chief-scientist-on-his-hopes-and-fears-for-the-future-of-ai/ |access-date=2023-11-01 |website=MIT Technology Review |language=en |archive-date=1 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231101193816/https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/10/26/1082398/exclusive-ilya-sutskever-openais-chief-scientist-on-his-hopes-and-fears-for-the-future-of-ai/ |url-status=live }} ==Career and research== [[File:Democratizing Deep Learning with Nervana and Google Brain (15105407149).jpg|thumb|Sutskever (second from right) at the Stanford Graduate School of Business in 2014]] From November to December 2012, Sutskever spent about two months as a [[postdoc]] with [[Andrew Ng]] at [[Stanford University]]. He then returned to the University of Toronto and joined Hinton's new research company DNNResearch, a [[University spin-off|spinoff]] of Hinton's research group. Four months later, in March 2013, Google acquired DNNResearch and hired Sutskever as a research scientist at [[Google Brain]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2013/03/google_hinton/|title=Google Hires Brains that Helped Supercharge Machine Learning|last=McMillan|first=Robert|date=13 March 2013|website=wired.com|access-date=9 November 2019|archive-date=16 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616190308/https://www.wired.com/2013/03/google_hinton/|url-status=live}} At Google Brain, Sutskever worked with [[Oriol Vinyals]] and [[Quoc Viet Le]] to create the [[seq2seq|sequence-to-sequence]] learning algorithm, and worked on [[TensorFlow]].{{cite q|Q29040034}} At the end of 2015, he left Google to become cofounder and chief scientist of the newly founded organization [[OpenAI]]. {{cite web|title=OpenAI Blog|date=12 December 2015|url=https://www.openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/|access-date=17 July 2016|archive-date=6 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211006105333/https://openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/|url-status=dead}}{{Official URL}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/04/openai-elon-musk-sam-altman-plan-to-set-artificial-intelligence-free/|title=Inside OpenAI, Elon Musk's Wild Plan to Set Artificial Intelligence Free|last=Metz|first=Cade|date=27 April 2016|website=wire.com|access-date=9 November 2019|archive-date=27 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427162700/http://www.wired.com/2016/04/openai-elon-musk-sam-altman-plan-to-set-artificial-intelligence-free/|url-status=live}} In 2023, he announced that he will co-lead OpenAI's new "Superalignment" project, which tries to solve the [[AI alignment|alignment]] of [[Superintelligence|superintelligences]] in 4 years. He wrote that even if superintelligence seems far off, it could happen this decade.{{Cite web |title=Introducing Superalignment |url=https://openai.com/blog/introducing-superalignment |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=openai.com |language=en-US |archive-date=14 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230714160436/https://openai.com/blog/introducing-superalignment |url-status=live }} Sutskever was formerly one of the six board members of the non-profit entity which controls OpenAI.{{cite web |title=Our structure |url=https://openai.com/our-structure |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230729203855/https://openai.com/our-structure |archive-date=29 July 2023 |access-date=2023-11-20 |quote=OpenAI is governed by the board of the OpenAI Nonprofit, composed of OpenAI Global, LLC employees Greg Brockman (Chairman & President), Ilya Sutskever (Chief Scientist), and Sam Altman (CEO), and non-employees Adam D’Angelo, Tasha McCauley, Helen Toner.}} [[The Information (website)|''The Information'']] speculated that the firing of Sam Altman in part resulted from a conflict over the extent to which the company should commit to [[AI safety]].{{Cite web |title=Before OpenAI Ousted Altman, Employees Disagreed Over AI 'Safety' |url=https://www.theinformation.com/articles/before-openai-ousted-altman-employees-disagreed-over-ai-safety |access-date=2023-11-20 |website=The Information |archive-date=18 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231118025046/https://www.theinformation.com/articles/before-openai-ousted-altman-employees-disagreed-over-ai-safety |url-status=live }} In a company all-hands meeting shortly after the board meeting, Sutskever stated that firing Altman was "the board doing its duty",{{cite web|first1=Benj|last1=Edwards|access-date=2023-11-20|title=Details emerge of surprise board coup that ousted CEO Sam Altman at OpenAI|url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/11/report-sutskever-led-board-coup-at-openai-that-ousted-altman-over-ai-safety-concerns/|date=2023-11-18|website=Ars Technica|archive-date=19 November 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231119020114/https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/11/report-sutskever-led-board-coup-at-openai-that-ousted-altman-over-ai-safety-concerns/|url-status=live}} though in the following week, he expressed regret at having participated in Altman's ousting.{{Cite news |last=Rosenberg |first=Scott |date=2023-11-20 |title=OpenAI's Sutskever says he regrets board's firing of Altman |work=Axios |url=https://www.axios.com/2023/11/20/sam-altman-fired-openai-board-illya-sutsever-regrets |access-date=2023-11-20}} The firing of Altman and resignation of Brockman led to resignation of three senior researchers from OpenAI.{{Cite web |last=Thompson |first=Polly |title=3 senior OpenAI researchers resign in the wake of Sam Altman's shock dismissal as CEO, report says |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/3-open-ai-researchers-resign-sam-altman-dismissal-ceo-2023-11 |access-date=2023-11-18 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US |archive-date=18 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231118180938/https://www.businessinsider.com/3-open-ai-researchers-resign-sam-altman-dismissal-ceo-2023-11 |url-status=live }} Following these events, Sutskever stepped down from the board of OpenAI.{{Cite web |date=22 November 2023 |title=OpenAI announces return of Sam Altman as CEO. |url=https://x.com/OpenAI/status/1727206187077370115?s=20 }} ===Awards and honours=== * 2015, Sutskever was named in [[MIT Technology Review]]'s 35 Innovators Under 35.{{cite web|title=35 Innovators Under 35: Ilya Sutskever|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2015/visionary/ilya-sutskever/|website=technologyreview.com|access-date=17 July 2016|archive-date=4 May 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504083506/https://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2015/visionary/ilya-sutskever/|url-status=live}} * 2018, Sutskever was the keynote speaker at [[Nvidia]] Ntech 2018{{cite web |last1=Martin |first1=Scott |title=Reinforcement Learning 'Really Works' for AI Against Pro Gamers, OpenAI Trailblazer Says |url=https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2018/09/14/reinforcement-learning-openai-pro-gamers-ilya-sutskeverai-elon-musk-gpu-dgx/ |access-date=28 March 2023 |website=Nvidia Blog |date=15 September 2018 |publisher=Nvidia |archive-date=28 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230328141735/https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2018/09/14/reinforcement-learning-openai-pro-gamers-ilya-sutskeverai-elon-musk-gpu-dgx/ |url-status=live }} and AI Frontiers Conference 2018.{{Cite web |title=The man who revolutionized computer vision, machine translation, games and robotics · AI Frontiers Conference |url=https://aifrontiers.com/2018/08/29/the-journey-of-openais-founder-ilya-sutskever-s-story/ |access-date=2023-06-16 |website=aifrontiers.com |archive-date=16 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230616151350/https://aifrontiers.com/2018/08/29/the-journey-of-openais-founder-ilya-sutskever-s-story/ |url-status=live }} * 2022, he was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] (FRS).{{Cite web|title=Ilya Sutskever|url=https://royalsociety.org/people/ilya-sutskever-35834/|access-date=12 May 2022|website=royalsociety.org|publisher=[[Royal Society]]|location=London|author=Anon|year=2022|archive-date=15 March 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230315060950/https://royalsociety.org/people/ilya-sutskever-35834/|url-status=live}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Wikiquote}} {{OpenAI navbox}} employees]] [[Category:Canadian computer scientists]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence researchers]] [[Category:Israeli expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Canadian expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:People from Nizhny Novgorod]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] {{Canada-scientist-stub}} {{compu-scientist-stub}}
